TINIDAZOLE

  • Indications and doses
  • Drug action
  • Pregnancy
  • Side effects
  • Cautions
  • Monitoring requirements
  • Unlicensed use
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Anaerobic infections,

By mouth

  • For adults
    Initially 2 g, followed by 1 g daily usually for 5–6 days, alternatively 500 mg twice daily usually for 5–6 days.

Bacterial vaginosis, Acute ulcerative gingivitis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    2 g for 1 single dose.

Abdominal surgery prophylaxis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    2 g for 1 single dose, to be administered approximately 12 hours before surgery.

Intestinal amoebiasis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    2 g once daily for 2–3 days.
  • For children 1 month–11 years
    50–60 mg/kg once daily (max. per dose 2 g) for 3 days.
  • For children 12–17 years
    2 g once daily for 2–3 days.

Amoebic involvement of liver,

By mouth

  • For adults
    1.5–2 g once daily for 3–6 days.
  • For children 1 month–11 years
    50–60 mg/kg once daily (max. per dose 2 g) for 5 days.
  • For children 12–17 years
    1.5–2 g once daily for 3–6 days.

Urogenital trichomoniasis, Giardiasis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    2 g for 1 single dose.
  • For children 1 month–11 years
    50–75 mg/kg (max. per dose 2 g) for 1 single dose, dose may be repeated once if necessary.
  • For children 12–17 years
    2 g for 1 single dose, dose may be repeated once if necessary.

Helicobacter pylori eradication,

By mouth

  • For adults
    (consult local protocol).

Drug action

Tinidazole is an antimicrobial drug with high activity against anaerobic bacteria and protozoa; it has a longer duration of action than metronidazole.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Manufacturer advises avoid in first trimester.

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Anorexia, furred tongue, gastro-intestinal disturbances, nausea, oral mucositis, taste disturbances, vomiting,

veryRare: Arthralgia, ataxia, darkening of urine, dizziness, drowsiness, erythema multiforme, headache, hepatitis, jaundice, leucopenia (on prolonged or intensive therapy), myalgia, pancreatitis, pancytopenia, peripheral neuropathy (on prolonged or intensive therapy), pruritus, psychotic disorders, rash, thrombocytopenia, transient epileptiform seizures (on prolonged or intensive therapy), visual disturbances,

notKnown: Aseptic meningitis, optic neuropathy,

Cautions regarding administration

  • Avoid in Acute porphyrias

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

Clinical and laboratory monitoring advised if treatment exceeds 10 days.

Unlicensed use

In children

Licensed for use in children (age range not specified by manufacturer).

Prepared medicinal forms of TINIDAZOLE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.
